LeadPara.Para: Before I turned 17, my family had moved eight times. In Honolulu, we lived in my maternal grandparents' house, a wooden plantation-style 1940s bungalow shaded from the late-afternoon sun by a copse of pink and red torch ginger that had grown so tall and dense that its leaves poked through the sea-glass-green jalousies. In New York we lived in an apartment building overlooking the East River, where all the residents with children would leave their front doors open during the day, turning the floors into a honeycombed communal space for us kids to inhabit. In Texas, before we moved into a house, we lived in a one-bedroom apartment, my brother and I sleeping in the living room on soft cotton chairs that unfolded into futon-like mattresses.

TailParas.Para: Because we were so transitory, I grew up associating the idea of home less with a physical structure than with the objects that inhabited it: A place became ours, mine, only when the 19th-century pine chest was positioned in the living room, when the early American quilt with its worn calico squares was hung on the wall, when our books had been unpacked and placed on the shelves.

That was one ritual. The other was the leave-taking. And with each place we departed, we left something behind, some evidence that, yes, we had been there, and that for a short time, we had possessed that space. In Baltimore, we left dozens of parrot tulips that had been my father's pride; in Texas, a vegetable garden of wildly curling squash vines where once there had been only silt; in Irvine, Calif. -- still, in the mid-'80s, rising from an empty stretch of clay -- my brother's and my heights, notched into a white-painted door frame.

The instinct to mark the place one has occupied in the world is not particular to humans -- animals create middens or nests made of saliva or dung or bits of straw -- but it is, like the very act of collecting objects, one of the impulses from which culture is born and defined. None of us can resist announcing our presence, no matter how temporal or humble our dwelling might be; we write ourselves into walls as a way of protesting the relentlessness, the uncaringness, of time.

Sometimes, as in the case of Alfred Liechtenstein and his wife, Alice, that transcription becomes its own sort of decoration. The Austrian castle they live in with their children is both a puzzle and a palimpsest: The first of its 52 rooms were built in the 12th century; Alfred's family has inhabited it since the 19th. Throughout, proof of ghosts from the past can be seen -- ancestors who have painted their portraits on its ceilings, who have etched their names into its surfaces. Now, the couple is leaving their own mark: a trippy Op Art-inspired elevator; a collection of furniture from contemporary designers. The castle is on loan to them from the generations that will succeed them, but for the moment, it's theirs.

Then there's the Polish-French artist Marc Camille Chaimowicz, whose uncategorizable art -- holistically conceived room-size works that smudge the line between decoration and installation -- is inseparable from his own London apartments, one of which he is vacating after nearly 40 years. To see it now, unchanged and preserved since the 1970s, with its palette of eau de nil and peach, its glossy painted chairs and hand-drawn murals, is to wonder whether you are seeing one man's home ... or an artistic projection of an idea of home. But it is also a reminder of our eternal, collective search for someplace we can call our own, for the place we imagine when we shut our eyes -- a yearning that takes on special meaning in our current age of refugees, who endure one of the great cruelties of the human experience: being forced to forsake their land for another. Chaimowicz's father, too, was a refugee, from a different era; it's perhaps not surprising that his very art is the recreation, again and again, of home. We say, with our spaces: We were here. Will you remember us? Memory is brief. But a house endures.
